Definition: Anything with computing power (e.g., mobile phone, laptop, raspberry pi, router)
Zeros and ones stored in a computer.
A representation of data.
The ability to read or write data on a computer.
A set of well-defined rules for how data is sent between computers.
Many computers connected by a protocol.
A computer that manages access to data in a network.
Many connected servers.
Many connected servers where each server has autonomy over access rules.
When a computer downloads the same data as another computer.
When multiple computers see the same information.
Each computer can act as a server for others, without needing a single (central) server.
A computer in a peer to peer network that uploads data to another computer.
A computer in a peer to peer network that downloads data from a seed.
A computer in a peer to peer network that both uploads and downloads data.
The process by which one peer is able to make a connection with another peer.
A server that makes it easier for peers to discover each other and replicates peer's data
A common data structure used across servers so that peers can discover each other.
When one computer (A) tells another computer (B) about data it received from a 3rd computer (C) without B and C talking directly.
A set of users who share some common data. Anyone can edit.
A set of peers on a peer to peer network that are all serving the same data.
An editable copy.
A two-part key used in cryptography to provide end-to-end encryption and signature verification.
The part of a keypair that can be used by others to verify a signature.
The part of a keypair that is used to create signatures and should be kept secret.
Data with associated cryptographic payload that confirms the creator of the data also possessed the associated private key at the time the data was created.
A number or string of characters that does not change and can be used to reference a piece of data at any point in time.
